awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  Accountability in Rebel Regimes
awd_abstract_narration:
The project investigates local governance and the establishment of law-like systems of order in territory controlled by rebel organizations during civil war. In particular, the project explains variation in rebel organizations' provision of public goods and services as well as their use of coercive violence against civilians to control territory. Departing from existing research, the argument examines civilian political mobilization and collective action to constrain rebel organizations, advancing a political accountability theory of rebel governance. Civilian communities with greater coordination capacity, the ability to achieve collective action to serve common interests despite distributional conflict, may well be more successful in controlling rebel behavior. The political accountability framework identifies the conditions conducive to rebel accountability and the tools of political participation available to civilians under rebel control. The result provides policymakers with a clear roadmap for how to strengthen and engage with war-affected communities. 

This theory is tested on a combination of qualitative and quantitative community-level evidence from insurgent-influenced areas in Mindanao, Philippines. The qualitative case comparison selects municipalities for variation in coordination capacity, the independent variable, and uses semi-structured interviews to "process trace" the link between community collective action and rebel behavior. The quantitative analysis examines an original survey of insurgent-influenced municipalities to be implemented in Northern and Central Mindanao. The findings will carry implications for academic and policy debates regarding the conduct of insurgency and the efficacy of counterinsurgency and peacebuilding strategies. Investigating the formation of law and order under the temporary breakdown of state sovereignty during civil war provides clear and consistent criteria for diagnosing strategic and tactical counterinsurgency challenges and an understanding how these conditions vary across locations within a given war zone.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of the project is to understand the conditions under which armed groups in competition with the state control territory, provide services and law-like systems of governance, and resort to civilian-targeted violence during civil war. In particular, the project aims to identify the conditions under which local non-combatant community members shape the conduct of rebel personnel on these dimensions. The existing literature largely marginalizes the role of civilians in shaping conflict processes, and this project provides a new framework fill this lacuna. I develop an accountability theory of rebel regimes, arguing that community collective action capacity shapes rebel personnel incentives regarding their investment in goods and services as well as the extent to which they will employ civilian-targeted violence to maintain control in particular communities. Communities with greater collective action capacity may mobilize members to collaborate with rebels conditional on good rebel governance as well as to foment resistance to rebels conditional on predatory exploitation or excessive use of violence. As a result, rebel personnel will be more willing to invest in providing services to the community in order to maintain the flow of collaboration and access to local resources in territory inhabited by communities with greater collective action capacity.

To test this theory, the project was designed to collect village-level quantitative and qualitative data from conflict-affected areas in a single case of civil war: the communist insurgency in the Philippines. The data were collected through a village-level key informant survey in historically conflict-affected areas of three provinces in the southern island of Mindanao, Philippines. The co-Investigator partnered with a team of researchers based in Davao City, Philippines to recruit one village leader or elder from each of 100 villages sampled from the three provinces in Mindanao: Compostela Valley, Davao Oriental, and Agusan del Sur. The research team interviewed each subject using the IRB-approved questionnaire. These interview subjects are community leaders or elders, selected to participate based on their extensive knowledge of the history in the village.

The goal was to measure various dimensions of rebel group governance, including law-like systems of law and order, in order to test the theoretical propositions advanced to explain the link between community social structure and variation in rebel group conduct. Community-level data on rebel conduct and governance is rare in the civil wars and political violence literature; the in-depth data collection in the particular case contributes to this gap in the empirical evidence available to test prevailing theories regarding rebel group behavior. In addition to the theoretical contribution to understanding the ways in which civilians shape conflict processes and the dynamics of political accountability in the absence of state institutions, the project also makes an important data contribution to a body of research in which systematic data collection on rebel group territorial control and governance is severely limited.

The process of collecting interviews was completed over the summer, at which point the research team turned towards transcribing the interviews and translating them into English. Many interviews have been translated and the Co-Investigator has begun the process of incorporating them into the quantitative and qualitative empirical test of the accountability theory of rebel regimes. However, the research team is still in the process of translating remaining interviews. Initial investigation of the interview transcripts suggests preliminary support for the accountability theory of rebel regimes: subjects reporting community rivalries and low generalized trust seem to report higher levels of victimization by rebel personnel. At this point in the process, it is too early to report definitive results supporting or falsifying the accountability theory of rebel regimes, because additional analysis is required to characterize repsonses on alternative factors in order to set up and conduct the controlled village case comparisons required to test the theory. The Co-Investigator plans to complete statistical analysis of the quantifiable responses by January 2017 and qualitative village case comparison analysis by April 2017. This timeline permits defense and final submission of the final dissertation manuscript, the main research output from the project, by June 2017. At that point in time, the results and conclusions from the research project can be reported to the NSF.
